title: Is the sum of two complex numbers always a complex number? - Quora

response.answer_text: Take two numbers w+ui x+yi Let's assume their sum is a non complex number v +0i (w + ui) + (x+ yi ) = v + 0i Using basic rules of complex addition, imaginary parts equal to imaginary parts u + y = 0 u = -y So if the imaginary parts of the two complex numbers are same with opposite sign the sum is purely real. Although real numbers are subset of complex numbers so yes, it is a complex number too. On the other hand, if you are asking whether complex numbers are closed under addition, ie. do we get numbers outside of the complex numbers then no, addition of two complex numbers will always give a number that falls under complex numbers or its subsets. If you were thinking, subtraction of counting numbers led to discovery of negative numbers and integers; division led to fractions, rationals, square root of negative gave complex numbers, is there anything beyond them? Then sure there is: there are quaternions and octonions. Google them for more details.
